instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Hi guys, this one has got me going crazy..... So i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight, usually my favourite repairs. Sometimes it works for a day and then its off again. Board looks superclean. Changed the display cable as these are not good in many cases, same issue. Changed the display for a know working one, same issue. 38-49v on the connector, so it has voltage. So I assumed it was inside the connector, which i eplaced, still the same issue. Is there any othe voltage/dataline i need to get backlight besides PPVOUT?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
39V is the correct voltage.
49V means open line to LED strips on the screen.

Do you always get image, only missing backlight?
Check <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA and <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> lines.
You should get o-scope activity when pressing backlight adjust keys.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: 39v is with the original display installed. 49v i got with my testing display, that is actually cracked.  Yes its always missing backlight, not a black display. When i turn it on display shows. I close the lid, open it again and the backlight is off. With a flashlight I can see the login screen. When i press the backlight adjustment keys the screen actually seems to blink. Will check these 2 lines now, what diode mode reading should these have?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I have 3.3v on <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>
on pin 3 & 4 5v on both with no display
On pin 3 -> 5v and pin 4 -> 3.1v with original display connected
Does that say something?

o-scope I have to do monday not at hand.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Wait, do you get normal image (with backlight) at first start?
Original Apple Magsafe 2 85W charger tried?
Do NOT use 1-->2 adapter for this machine!
Also try disconnecting internal SSD; use USB OSX.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Your test screen is the wrong screen so only use the broken one. At 39 volts it should work..measure <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> when it doesn?t work
